text: hi my name is Craig Simon I'm a Senior
Solutions architect with
AWS today I'm going to spend a few
minutes walking through a demonstration
of a product that we released called AWS
verified access or Ava now what is Ava
Ava is a zero trust service so it allows
us to securely deploy applications HTML
based applications to to the internet
without having to store them inside of a
secure enclave and then provide VPN
access back into this Enclave instead we
can place a public endpoint directly on
the internet but we can protect and
secure that endpoint so that only those
users that we want access the
application can gain it and we can
control to a very precise level what
each user can do to that application all
accesses both approved and disallowed
are logged so have an entire log Trail
around all of the application accesses
and then I can securely configure Ava in
such a way that I can use another system
called Ram or resource access manager to
share my secured configuration so most
of the time what I might want to do is I
might want my appsc or my centralized
security team to securely configure the
AA service then they'll share those Ava
groups off to application teams so those
application teams are able to then
deploy those applications and use those
endpoints that I've created but I'm able
to enforce policy and I'm able to make
sure that the security constraints that
I want to apply to these pinpoints is in
place even though another team is
responsible for actually placing their
application there so I'd like to take us
a couple of minutes to address a
question which we hear from customers
relatively often which is what is the
easiest what's the best way for me to be
able to scale Ava in my
organization
and I talked about it to this point but
I really want to go ah and address that
specifically it's the combination of Ava

centrally manage Ava and then enforce
and push that configuration down onto
the application teams so using Ava a
Central Security team can configure um
their AA instance they can configure the
user and divider trust device trust
providers they can build policies apply

that only certain groups certain people
are able to connect to the
endpoints then using Ram they can push
that configuration down to the

configuration will be enforced because
the underlying configuration for Ava is

central level so all the policies all
the trust providers all the other limits
logging configuration and everything
that that Central team places will be
enforced by those application teams
using that so you can ensure that those

want them to but again that centralized
security team doesn't have to manage the

everything else they get to go ahead and
have those application teams manage that
